header.rec_loc: Home of ANON in Oval, Lambeth, South London
header.topics: Birth of grandchild. Being born abroad. What things are like in France: property, enterprise, land, anarchists and bureaucrats, French visitors to London. Chichester Cathedral spire collapsing. Architect called Porden. Open day and photo exhibition. Art competition. Argument about bollards. Local housing management: failings of new landlord. Book being written by speaker no 2. British Library. Philip of Spain and Mary Tudor: experience of visiting Spanish archives. Austrian battleship disaster. Historians.
header.activity: Friends talking about Europe, history and local concerns
header.conv_type: Discussingm explaining, inquiring, advising, anecdote telling

is not particularly compatible with the
with the MP3 and the other
sort of software that you have
to record music and stuff like that because erm they're you know they're all Apple people
those people they like Apple better
but erm so the idea is just that we kind of chat away
so erm erm probably erm so erm you it's your your daughter that you went out to see when they she had her babies wasn't it? you were going out to see

yes that's right yes she erm had her first baby er exactly just almost to the day that they had to leave Berlin and then and move into the house in Brussels and er er we went over had to come over to London to have the child erm in the typically erm I suppose it's a reprehensible way I put my foot down and said my grandson is going to be born in this country
and I'm not having any kraut grandchildren thank you and er so she came over here and gave birth erm er in
erm well what's it called? er it was
oh yeah yeah yeah yeah yeah

so I don't know how that works though because my my nephew was born in Bahrain and erm and I was never sure whether that meant that there was some kind of question mark over his I mean both his parents are British but
you know if you're born overseas I don't know where that leaves you whether there's the kind of there's just that little trace there in your heritage where people say
you'll have to be careful you will have to make sure that the er er British authorities know when it happened
and so you have to tell the local consul
and so on unless they've changed it or unless the the rules in the European Union may be different but it was essential that er ththose two little children were born in England
so that they could haha where there wouldn't be any problem about them beco them becoming British subjects

well I was yes I was slightly concerned with my sister as I thought you know actually erm you do find that people who are born and spend their early lives with their peripatetic parents sometimes don't develop roots
my second son was born in Paris his mother is French and erm she then she's quite a clued up lady erm she moved from Paris and worked for one of the er depdepartment authorities in southwest France

and that's where first went to school then he came back to England and when he came back to England erm I had to er register him and take out British nationality for him and it I even h even had to go to the lengths of getting a copy of the his French birth certificate with my name on it
yes they may have changed all that this was in nineteen erm eight nineteen the nineteen eighties
I wouldn't have thought it was easier now I would have thought it was more difficult now because there are so many
ye I think it is more difficult
I mean and we are actually getting worse
about even Europeans coming here aren't we?
don't know where all that's going to end I mean I know my mother when she first came to the country had to go to the police station every week and register
where where had she come from?
well she was born in Toulouse
at one part went to or whatever it's called
in in in and because of er the work
and they they put a lot of money into all the educational facilities and he got an internship with
and from he got himself a place at one of the London university colleges er it's a bit stupid I can't remember whether it's or something like that but
erm and he went to a London university but it was quite a business and while he was at the London university the I had to deal with the business of his citizenship
but only when he was I dunno he must have been er seventeen or eighteen yeah

whereas the French I was talking to my mother about this the other day you know I could get a French passport if I wanted one and erm and my siblings have done so erm but they all reported how snotty the people were at the French embassy when you went there
and they were all sort of very disdainful and looked down their nose at you
can I help you? what are you doing here?
so I've always sort of put off the business of going to to get a French passport as well but there were various times when erm for example wrote to me and asked me if I'd like to vote
er because erm obviously he felt that it would help his cause I suppose
so but I think they seem to have a very different attitude to to us have you got property in France?
no no no no I'm glad erm I wouldn't want to have either
I I wouldn't want to live in France it's a nightmare country
it's er oh gosh it's awful
you know no er I mean the only sensible thing that any French people do is come over over here why do you think there are so many people French over here?
well I don't know I mean
well the rea I'll tell you exactly why if you've got any initiative at all er er you want to set up your own business for example

or you go into a big firm like erm er Thomson-CSF which is the biggest armaments comcompany erm and erm you get very well trained up you ha they insist on you having all these qualifications and so on half of which you don't need
erm and unless you have them you can't get a job

erm and then if you want to set up your own because you can see all the the er on-cost of the bureaucracy which these large firms are stuck with the minute you set up a company you have to pay tax whether you've made a profit or not it stifles all initiative it's quite extraordinary

and I'll tell you another thing if you have and this is from past experience if you have a house or a share in a house and you want to share that house you have to do it through a a er an agent appointed appointed not chosen by you appointed by the state
and he acts as a a erm a mediator and whoever is buying the you know er property has to use that person as well
and so if you erm say well you you think the man is getting it all wrong er firing the guy is well a very expensive job in in fact
it it their system of doing things is is weird
oh yes that's it's beyond belief
my mother inherited her mother's house and
she was obviously very sentisentimental about it and wanted to keep it but that wa this was in a suburb of Bordeaux

so it wasn't it just wasn't feasible as a holiday house and er so she let it out and you're not allowed to evict any tenants between November and April because you're not allowed to evict tenants during the winter because of the potential hardship of the tenant
so even if they're not paying you rent you're not allowed to evict them

erm it all went so horribly horribly wrong over the years that and she got fleeced terribly by this this one man erm who really sort of took liberties and then when she came to sell it she had that same situation where you have the
the person who brokers the sale

and the only saving grace of it is that in order to avoid death duties and capital gains and stuff like they're they the the appointed agent will at some point or another leave the room whereupon packages of money are exchanged under the table
between the buyer and the seller because you have an official selling price
which is sort of set a price where you know which is quite an innocuous sort of price
that doesn't attract any attention from the authorities
and then there's the real sales price
which is negotiated privately on the side
so you know you have pieces of paper on the table
that says the house is being sold for X and then an envelope with
the balance of the money gets passed underneath the table while the guy is is is looking in the other direction erm so erm so the French have found a way around the bureaucracy

in fact I think really but but that's not to say that erm the state is not a bit erm oppressive in that re in that regard I suppose that's one of the reasons why they don't have the same problems in Paris that they do over here with this sort of young people trying to find rented accommodation because you you know there is not that property ownership thing there not a fetishistic thing
all and er all the land and I know that that but all the land in Paris belongs to the state
it doesn't belong to various individuals

my aunt had a house er in er erm er Montan I can Montan and my great aunt also had a house down there as well erm and they were always having trouble with er getting permission to do this or having this that and the other done
and so on and you have to oil everybody's hands and
otherwise you just never get anywhere er

no it is erm no my father was though is always that he wants to move there because erm they don't have oh well until recently they haven't had the same thing about speeding so you could drive how you wanted and however fast you wanted
and you were okay and also you know he felt that erm oh he had a thing about David Blunkett introducing all these laws about gun owning guns and things like that
he just tha the French are the French are more grown up and reasonable about about erm you know erm not erm infantalising I suppose people or
seeking to be very parental about about how they live their lives and what they have and what they do and
and so on but I don't I think the French are catching up with us in that regard actually
their inheritance laws are are bizarre
erm you can't make a will in a way that you can here
no cos you can't it things get inherited by your children don't they not by your spouse?
er that's correct and and also you can't erm er just er er write a will saying I leave all my property to a cats' home
or I leave all my property to my second son
not my first son and it doesn't matter if you put in the fact that you s first son has made a million anything like that oh no the law has to operate
so it's a feudal then really isn't it? or sort of
well it's dictatorial and it's a totalitarian is sort of
er however you wanna call it
but I suppose it's about you know perhaps it's about land perhaps it's about you know the family farm going down through the generations or something
mm I think er er er er I think it's a erm an intellectual approach I would say rather crudely that all French people suffer from the pr what I call the promised land syndrome
er if you they all quote Rousseau at you

erm about every man is free and all that sort of nonsense and erm er they entirely o they had this vision that they all had this vision of a perfect state where everybody is properly looked after and as some people here say everybody has a prize
and so on they don't stop to think about the practicalities of it and the result of that is that they're for example their er farming agricultural industry is chronically inefficient
because none of the units are the right size

er they don't once you build up a a or you reach a what I think you call a critical mass on the farm for example you get the right amount of machinery and get it erm capitalised properly used properly so that it was worth spending money for example on a a forty thousand pound combine harvester and there's no point in having a piece of machinery like that if you've only got twenty acres

but it once you get to the right level of saying five hundred acres or might probably be a thousand acres in fact erm er then when you die they will say oh no that's all got to be split up again and so they they're constantly destroying the ececonomic base of their agriculture
that is very weird isn't it?

gosh I suppose they've got a lot of land though haven't they? perhaps er perhaps they're not they haven't got the same sort of the the panic about it that we do cos we're always sort of saying oh we're running out we're running out of land there's not enough room whereas France is very spread out and sometimes actually
you look at the way the French sort of set things out and you think you're being very careless actually with your

it's funny that you say that because erm French people coming over here erm we've er taken erm er peo like and her sister and so on down to and the thing that they always say is oh the countryside in England is manicured
er er which I find weird actually because when you drive around er the suburbs of Paris where there are gardens or in Normandy where there are good farms they look after them
because they have this sense of style or
whatever it is and everything has to be very presentable
well even in the middle where there's very little and very few people
when you drive across it's all
it's all you know you it's not like being in America where you've got the Badlands or wild quite wild country
that's not obvious that it belongs to anybody it's all terribly cultivated
I'm sure you read about the guy who was not allowed to run a ski school
erm his his mother erm finished up looking after one of the departments in the in the Pyrenees
and as a result of that he got the opportunity to ski right through I think two or three winters and got himself qualified as a ski instructor
but they wowon't allow for example is just as good if not better skier but he's not allowed to instruct at all
because has hasn't gone through the rigmarole of taking all these exams
and erm this that and the other and so on
well I don't know I I often think the French are fifty percent of them are bureaucrats and the other half are anarchists
yes that's just about true yes
and they kind of hold each other in a state of
my mother's definitely on er on the anarchic side actually

she's she went to some you know if you have the misfortune to go into a courtroom with her or something and you stand up when the judge comes in my mother's sitting there starting to go I don't see why I should have to stand up for him he's only a human being like the rest of us
er at one point erm I'm I I I had a heart attack and erm I thought while I while I was recovering I couldn't work I will erm er er brush up my German so I went to college
and er in and er it it it's a I think it's a a college of further education or whatever they call it anyway
er it's very the language language department is very well run the head of the language department is a French lady
and her sister she introduced me to her sister her sister is the most joyous individual she is one of the anarchists
and you know erm in I think it was in Nicaragua
erm or one of those Central American erm countries they what do they call the com c can you remember what they were called?
mm anyway somehow she got herself into a position of editing the a book by one of these I wish I could remember what they're called erm they're rrrrebels against the Americans at any rate
erm and er I got to know her quite well and she certainly had anarchist tendencies and on one occasion the book was being published in Paris and so

she er was going backwards and forwards and er she was doing a job I think also I dunno if it was in college but it was something to do with education anyway erm and er she went over to Paris and she came back absolutely knackered and I said
what on earth? you know oh she said there was a manif I said what? she said yes we there was a very good manif on the Champs-Elysees what would be what she meant was there was a demonstration
erm about something or other which something had done I said what was it all about? it took me about two hours to discover that she really hadn't a clue what the demonstration was about
she joined in because it was a good party
it's the most extraordinary performance to be fair at the end of it all she gave me a signed copy of the book which had been published
which was rather fun and it was all about smuggling things like bicycles
now into central America well I always thought central America was er you know straight up and down no flatlands at all but
the thought of bicycling around Nicaragua oh I wish I could remember what they were called ththese people
oh no I my brain has gone as well now
but but the the sort of villain of the piece was a man called Noriega I think
Confindustria er Confindustria for the Italian erm CPI not that contra something or other
it was quite a interesting experience
er but I've got to know quite a lot of French people and really quite well and
you seem to have a constant stream of French people actually
we do yes because they like coming over here
they live in Primark getting our our
oh I know well the little girls we have at the brics who are all
all from this school in Bordeaux
and we have a link with a school in Bordeaux because when I was growing up erm there was a young woman called who used to come over in the holidays and look after us
and er she had a student she then went on to be a student and and

this stu one of her students said to her I need a placement in England so sh phoned me up and said could you take a student? and then since then we've been taking two a year so we have we had this sort of who's a fellow trustee said erm oh yes I've just been looking at the people who have been visiting our website and looking at the statistics and strangely we seem to have a lot of people in Bordeaux looking at our website
so I said yes it's all the students that go to a particular school researching us

before they write to us and say can I come over and do two months' placement with you so erm so we have this ongoing link with erm with the students in Bordeaux but they all come over here and erm they're very naive really about what to expect when they get to London and some of them have the most horrible adventures with

so and they're cos they're always trying to economise by finding you know finding flats on the internet and you can't tell them that London's a big place and it's full of strangers and that that actually you can't trust anybody you meet on the internet and there's one girl
in particular who got awfully stung and erm and er somebody took about two thousand euros off her in advance
er rental on a flat and turned out to be
a complete fake and the flat didn't exist and
so they do they do actually fall er get themselves into trouble from time to time
yeah I spent a day Bordeaux is a rather a nice place actually I think
had very happy times there er when I was working in cathedral they sent me to France to find out how they look after the cathedrals there
and er I was the the

er Bordeaux erm and the reason I was sent to Bordeaux was because it was English for such a very long time and they were actually keen to find out the the clerk of the works and his erm people in were keen to find out whether er anybo there'd been any exchange of er craftsmen and technology between
and the er Chi two particular cathedrals Chichester and and erm Salisbury
I don't know if you've have you been to Chichester? the the the point

but it's it's as the cathedral is very interesting one one of the most quirky and interesting things about it is that a man was in the nave with a box original box camera in eighteen sixty something when the spire imploded
and he er he managed to take photographs of it actually happening

er and and they're really primitive pictures but you can see it's most interesting things because you can see that once the er the inner cement so to speak mortar mortar started to crumble the weight er you it it went like that er right down
yes really strange and the other thing that
I had no idea that had happened
erm the you can and well if you go there you will see the photographs

and the other thing about er er Chichester is that there is still to this day erm they have a a a proper international stone yard er an awful lot of er churches in the south of England use quoin stone
yes uhu er and if for example Peterborough which is miles up er erm that's got
it's quite near the eastern coast if
it would go up the River Nene in a
so perhaps it was that so you sort of went up that side of the country to get to

there is of craftsmen erm it's quite limited
erm there's no what I call what they quite heavy lifting erm they didn't er pick up any erm constructive technology from er Bordeaux
no all of that came from mm er particularly from the Abbey at St Denis
actually erm and to Canterbury and so on
but craftsmen individual craftsmen were going
individual craftsmen who would go and do for example ththat they you must have seen bosses the stone bosses
which are beautifully carved and and some there was an interchange between craftsmen from France coming through England
nobody er nobody knows quite who was the engineering brain behind Salisbury cathedral because it it it's it is an engineering feat

well then er they are just when you look at them and think about what the must have been involved in conceiving them and building them then I mean well it must have taken well it did take decades in some instances didn't it to put them up? there's that wonderful erm William Golding novel called The Spire
oh yes that's right that's right absolutely you know
and I think it's an absolutely fantastic book
a man of a man obsessed really yes we we managed to find something about the architecture of erm for erm erm 's son was helping us out a bit

but he he only ever sort of led on one building which was our building
but erm but you know he was erm he he got quite good press for it really in those days
but there was a street named after him
but I've never found a I've never heard of any come across any other building that's put up by him
there were some there were other churches he worked on as part of a team for a boss but is his only his only ssole creation really
so so that's it that was fun that was quite fun to find that out actually so we we this this open day thing was quite good for us it was it was
I'd noticed you'd put some lovely erm prints or drawings up as you go in at the bottom of the lift
no that's my little photographic expedition
all these photographs from the archives
there's quite a that quite an amazing of the spire of across the fields because it was there
before all the houses came so
so it's sort of standing on its own in the middle of an orchard or something
which is hard to imagine these days with er all that traffic rushing past us
do you still have an annual art exhibition?
so and actually who is the art teacher is now
now running classes on our building as well so so that's actua so I'm hoping that we're going to reposition ourselves and be a bit more artistic have a few more kind of
kind of of that sort of class going on
where people pay for it apparently erm
there'll be er er on the twenty-ninth there'll be a girl erm there called
I'll introduce you to her she works for
and erm well you might find it quite a useful link I don't know
er because they've got a lot er er a large educational programme
I think you were trying you there was somebody before wasn't there?
yes there was yes there was
I mean years ago and didn't come off for some reason
I can't remember what that was the
oh I think the reason it came o didn't come off was cos I think I got ill
erm erm and I had to postpone meetings I've I've I've er do remember that actually
I think there might ha it was also there was something else as well I don't remem I think there was can't remember what the problem
I certainly arranged for somebody from the to talk to actually
that I know that that did come off erm
oh I think but I think it might have been one of those things where there was one conversation and then one person said that I need to pass you on to another person and then as so often happens
despite good intentions on both sides and I I think

the timing the timing cos of the timing of the art competition or something it didn't work out I can't remember but erm no it's been it's been erm no we still do it and we still have our little French students helping us out it's a way of kind of marketing without marketing really
but as the open day was a way of marketing

cos that I think you know it has limited I don't know how we've we market ourselves I think the best way is to have people in the hall and saying you know oh what a lovely hall I think I might come back here
so so we're having all kinds of difficulties with er with er with the congregation again of course
well we were having an argument er there was the most surreal argument at the AGM about the bollards because there was
because there were there was a few instants where the people who run the nightclub opposite were just taking over the car park at night and there were a couple of er attacks stabbings
where the perpetrators were loitering in our car park and jumping out on people in and

and then jumping in the car and rushing off and there was also lots of drug dealing so we decided that that we were going to lock the bollards so we had a rather surreal conversation where we had a delegation from the church demanding that they be allowed to have a bollard please so given that we were reporting on the fact that our finances were up the creek at the time
and then they turned up and said yeah but yeah but can please can we have a bollard please?
so as usual a completely disproportionate response to er
so anyway so you've begun to when you retired you were going to sort of help the the the association round here but did you did your estate here get taken over in the end by an or a whatever it was?
yeyes what happened er was that er the council erm they er wanted to get rid of responsibility for all their freehold on what was originally the estate
I presume this was enough to win a bombsite or something
or did they knock it down deldeliberately?
they didn't knock it down deliberately?
no no no it was it was it was
flaflattened and er well what er what then happened was that er the tenants and residents association erm put together a a a sh I think they called it a shadow regeneration board

erm and I er er they erm er selected the they interviewed and s er and then selected a er housing association housing ass housing trust erm and at that point erm it this er there was a meeting of the tenants and residents association and a presentation was made by somebody from this shadow board and I started asking questions and erm I was asked to join the board
and er er we were responsible for er putting together a package er which covered all the functions which er had been discharged by the council
to service their tenants on this estate and that was er the the terms the legislation which provides for the transfer away from the council to a recognised housing
association and that has to be voted on

and there was a a a a ballot er based on the proposals which the this shadow board had agreed erm and everybody mm by an an a marginal majority I don't think it was about th twenty votes so to speak I d two hundred and something erm they decided against it
yours truly being I was rather surprised from talking to people because I thought it would be passed on a nod almost
I discovered that that the ballot had been rigged
and that people had been going round erm er er er er saying er ca to people who in in the two wings that are sheltered that's all sheltered housing
at the far far end knocking on the doors and say oh give us your erm er er voting er card and we'll put it in the ballot ballot box and erm
they'd they'd either been telling people how to vote or they'd just not been putting the er papers in the ballot box
and the the the truth of it was that the electoral that the ballot was carried out by the I think it's called the electoral reform society
and they had been so slovenly er they they should
they're supposed to be the people who are the example of how to do this
they were not they were just lazy
idle and so we erm wwe we had to go to get to approach the minister of state who is a good lady called
erm and er with 's help erm yours truly wrote to and said can we please have a revamp? and that was the agreed the gov the department of the environment I think it was called
they said yes and erm the second time round the offer made by erm metropolitan
and then erm the offer was based on metropolitan spending twenty-four million pounds
on the regeneration of the estate
erm and er er the the board the shadow board was er er given permanent er status so to speak and er it it had to allow for a a rotation in membership
and I er volunteered to stand down erm after the first I think it was two years erm and er it it had erm mm we had approved the initial essential work programme
the sort of urgent repairs that needed doing and then I stood down but just before I stood down er they came up they discovered there was er asbestos all over the place
yeah and erm ththey the health and safety people moved in
and said you've got to take all this asbestos out and it was blue or brown or pink or I don't know what what it was and er
yyeah it was the harmful sort yeah
erm and er er we were told that we if we had this could have it done for free
erm and I said well that's fine but I w I want want a contract and so on and I said no can't do things for free that it's not like they could do things
and the was so slovenly and just generally uncooperative because they also at the same time erm were proposing to redo redo the rooves

er of the houses er which had got asbestos in them and so we sai which er which was freehold which we all said well if you're going to do redo this those er rooves can't you do our rooves as well? they said oh no they said no and
one way or another I just got and we all got completely fed up

with I'm not quite sure where the problem lay but at at a higher level in the local people because all the people we'd originally been dealing with they suddenly they all resigned they vanished and we got a lot of people trying to run this replacement of the they are called fascia boards where the asbestos was er of cour didn't know their way round the estate they were er
er I think it it was very unsatisfactory the whole thing and er they'd been erm I'm out of it now but I I just got completely browned off
er er it was really tiresome
not surprised and I think some of these ass that some of these housing associations claim they overreach themselves and
well they've got very weak management

and they don't pay attention to details they they ssent us round at the end of the repl the replacing of the fascia boards they gave us all erm a a letter er saying this is what we've done and it it it literally did not make sense it
and so we had had to you know er er we get to issue new letters and then erm it's in in the case of our house erm and it said that they had replaced the Vent-Axia erm the extractor fan they hadn't
and er er and in one of the houses

two two or three down that way erm fortunately er the the freeholder erm er noticed the work was being done when she was not aware it was about to be done and she she'd found that the guy who was doing the work had muddled up the numbers
and he was doing work which should have been for
on number eighty-three and number eighty-four you know when you come up the street and the houses
on that side are completely different?
there's a small dock which belonged to the council
should have been doing a job on that on the house over there
and he was doing trying to do that sort of just didn't work at all
I remember once getting a free boiler service like that
when somebody was supposed to be at somebody else's house but it's not very satisfactory is it really? that's bizarre isn't it? so erm have you lived here since it was new?
since this this was new this house?
no no the the houses were built in nineteen sixty-seven
and er erm they were privatised by wait a minute n that's not no nineteen seventy-six that's
ni seventy-six and then Mrs Thatcher introduced the er sale of council houses and er er about er I think it's actually over fifty percent of the houses here w have been privatised
yeah and this house was erm the tenant was a builder erm and he made various changes erm including disconnecting the house from the communal heating
erm which in fact was a erm a a really sensible thing to do
bubut it meant that we had extraordinary pipework erm sticking up into the kitchen this wall was about where you are now
where you and I are now and there there was a a curious pipe connection sticking up into the middle of the kitchen it was really very very odd indeed

but the disconnect the the discontinuance of the communal heating system was one of the erm jobs which er was supposed to do erm and er they mmade a Horlicks of that too they didn't realise that half of the estate is erm on the front level
and where that is the case the erm the houses are built in pairs in fact
and underneath that wall and not under this this wall but under the next wall erm there was a a er like a er a solid wall
so that no water can pass through one to the other
erm just pipes and that's all and then the the wall here is is it isn't any longer but it was relatively it had a big hole in it in fact
erm and there is a tunnel which you can er go through er which was built originally erm as a er er like a a test it's for it's you need to find out where the heating could go whwhere
where there were other pipes and so on
but when they when discontinued the communal heating they didn't realise that er these walls must be replaced otherwise if there was a a the I think it's called the river
oh the right it's here as well is it?
and if if there's if there's a very high tide
